4493711/4413567/4534496.title: Our Local Graveyard
4493711/4413567/4534496.text: Our graveyard is situated in the Crossroads. It is in the RC Church grounds. It is about an acre in area. It must be over a hundred years opened. The old graveyard was in Kilkadden. Untill 1935 the old school house was in the Graveyard Many of the old head stones are of the flat kind. The inscriptions are faded and hard to read. I read one which was dated 1806. The grave yard contains two vaults. A monument of ancient appearance stands in a corner. I found one Iorn Cross. There is special corner for unbaptized children. There is no person buried within the church,but the graves of ten Priests are in the graveyard. The graves are numbered with Iorn Crosses. The graveyard has been recently improved. It was drained and walks were made through it.

4493769/4418463/4534534.title: The Old Graveyards
4493769/4418463/4534534.text: There are three graveyards in this district, and they are still in use, Drumhaggart, Iskaheen, and Muff.  They are about two miles distant from each other.  Drumhaggart graveyard is situated in the townland of Drumhaggart, and it is a very old graveyard.  In former times both Catholics and Protestants were buried in it, but only Protestants are buried in it now.  There is no church near to it, but there is the ruin of a abbey or church beside it.  Iskaheen graveyard is situated in the townland of Iskaheen beside the Catholic church.  Some of the tombstones are of stone and some of marble.  There are also a few small crosses in it, some of them are made of wood and some of iron.  Muff graveyard is situated in the townland of  Muff beside the Protestant church.

4493769/4418464/4534535.title: The Old Graveyards
4493769/4418464/4534535.text: There are three churchyards in the parish, Iskaheen, Muff, and Drumhaggart.  Iskaheen churchyard is situated in the townland of Iskaheen.  Muff churchyard in the townland of Muff, and Drumhaggart in the townland of Drumhaggart.  They are all still in use.  There is a church in Muff graveyard, and a church and a ruin at Iskaheen graveyard, and there is a ruined church or abbey beside Drumhaggart.  Iskaheen and Drumhaggart graveyards are sloping south-east and Muff is level.  In Iskaheen graveyard there are some old tombstones.  On one tombstone are the dates 1661 and 1663.  Drumhaggart graveyard is one of the oldest graveyards in the country.  There are crosses made of wood and iron in these graveyards.

4493769/4418465/4534540.title: The Old Graveyards
4493769/4418465/4534540.text: There are three graveyards in the parish of Muff, Co. Donegal.  Iskaheen graveyard is situated in the townland of Iskaheen.  Muff graveyard is situated in the townland of Muff.  Drumhaggart graveyard is situated in the townland of Drumhaggart.  They are all still in use.  There is a church and a ruin in Iskaheen graveyard.  There is a church in Muff graveyard, and there is a ruin beside Drumhaggart graveyard but no church.  Iskaheen and Drumhaggart graveyards slope south-east.  Muff is level.  There is one very old tomb in Iskaheen graveyard and this is what is written on it:- Heare - lyeth - the - body - of - John . Guinn . who . desesed . the . 28 . of . February . 1661 . and . his . wife . who . desesed . the . 23 . July . 1663.  On this tombstone are carvings of a skull, two spades and a pick.  Also the letters R.G. below.  There are people buried inside the ruin in Iskaheen graveyard.

4493758/4417368/4535328.title: The Local Forge
4493758/4417368/4535328.text:
(continued from previous page)
The tools the blacksmith uses are chisels and many other things. He was many horse shoes hanging from one side of the forge. There is a clay floor in the forge but the piece of the floor at the foot is boarded for the horses to stand on. Blacksmiths are always thought to be very strong.



There is a forge is near the town.  It is about half a mile out of the town.  It is along the mian road.  His name is Nealy Gamble.  There is two men in that forge.  He makes harrows and grobers.  His father was in that forge be fore him.  It is a sment floor and has a small door.  They smith has power too put rats out of a house.  The smith makes tonges and pots.  His brother is in the forge too.  They sparks that flyd from the red iron is in the singe of a good shoe.  The smith is very strong and has strong arms.  And he fixes ploughs and double ploughs and graves.



There is a churchyard in green hill.  There is the ruins of a church and a grave yard there.   There is a square grave yard in Greenhill.  It is in the town land of Greenhill.  The gate of greenhill church is built up now.  This church in Greenhill is never used now.  This grave yard is sloping to the west.
(continues on next page)

4493758/4417369/4535331.title: The Old Graveyards
4493758/4417369/4535331.text:
(continued from previous page)
There is another churchyard in Deserteganey. This churchyard is in use now. This churchyard was opened in green hill chapel was closed. People can remember burials in Green Hill churchyard. There is a graveyard attached o the other church in Deserteganey.



13/12/1938 John McLaughlin (58) Keelogs Buncrana Co Donegal.Long ago there used to be a Caman match in Stragill every Christmas day. There was eleven playing on  every side. They played in a field in Stragill Buncrana. It is in the townland of Stragill. They played between two town lands. The people made the caman sticks themselves. They got a bit of a stick
(continues on next page)

4493777/4419413/4535942.title: Local Graveyards
4493777/4419413/4535942.text: We have a good many graveyards in this place. We have one at Clare, one at Redcastle, one at Drung, and one at Greenbank. These graveyards are still in use. Some of these graveyards are very old and others are not so old. The one at Greenbank is not so old, but the others are old.   There are no trees growing in Redcastle graveyard, but there are trees growing in the other graveyards. In Redcastle there are flat stones, and there is a little cave in it. There are people buried in the cave.   There are old churches at Redcastle and Drung. There are people buried in these old churches. Clare graveyard is flat but the others are not flat. Clare graveyard is facing east the other graveyards are facing south. Un-baptised babies are buried in a part of the graveyard by themselves.

4493777/4419414/4535943.title: Local Graveyards
4493777/4419414/4535943.text: There is a graveyard at Redcastle church. There are a lot of old graves in that graveyard. There is an old ruin of a church in the graveyard. There are people buried inside the old ruin. Some of the graves are about one hundred years old. There are a lot of headstones in the graveyard. There is a stone wall all around the graveyard and iron gates. There is a stable inside the graveyard.   There is a graveyard at Drung were children who are not baptised are buried. There is a graveyard at Drung chapel. There is a stone wall round it. There are a lot of graves in that graveyard. Some graves has headstones and others has none.

4493777/4419415/4535945.title: Local Graveyards
4493777/4419415/4535945.text: There are a lot of graveyards in this parish. There are one at Greenbank, Drung, Redcastle, Clare, Cooley, and Muff. Some of these graveyards are used but others are not used. Greenbank graveyard is used and Drung graveyard is used and Redcastle graveyard is used.. Clare graveyard is not used, Cooley graveyard is not used, and Muff graveyard is not used.   Greenbank graveyard is sloped towards the South East. Drung graveyard is sloped towards the South East, Redcastle graveyard is sloped towards the South. Clare graveyard is level. Cooley graveyard is level. There are none of these graveyards circular.    There are very old people buried in Redcastle called the Carey's. There are ruins of an old church in Redcastle graveyard and there are people buried inside the ruins.

4493777/4419416/4535947.title: Local Graveyards
4493777/4419416/4535947.text: There is a graveyard at a place in Drung calledCaldragh. There is no church at the graveyard in Drung. It is a place where unbaptised children are buried.    There is another graveyard in Drung. It is an old graveyard. There is a church at this graveyard. There is also the ruins of an old church beside this one that St Colmcille built. The oldest of the graves in it is 1784. This is over 150 years ago. There are two burying grounds at this church.   Greenbank is another of the local churches. It is not long built. It is not a very old church. There is a burying ground at this church and it is still in use.

4493783/4420398/4535954.title: Old Graveyards
4493783/4420398/4535954.text: There are three churches in this parish. Ballyhack church is called St Mary's. The convent chapel is St Michaels and Ballinacré.These churches are still in use. None of the churchyards are round in shape. Trees grow in the churchyards. Some of these tomb stones are very old and also crosses. Some of these stones are ornamented.Some crosses are made of wood. Ballyback and Ballinacré  are where the graveyards are. There is a plot of ground in the graveyard for unbaptized children.There was a graveyard at Cille Blaney(?) Shrove. It was used by the people for unbaptized children. It is not used now.Long ago there was a chapel called Cille Brighdhe. There are no ruins to be seen now. There is also a graveyard. There is a holy water font at the graveyard. This is where mass was said long ago. The oldest tombstone I ever heard of was Fr. Wm. Doherty's  1844 at Ballyback(?). A child the name of Perkins was buried at Cill Blaney thirty seven years ago.

4493784/4420006/4536462.title: The Graveyard Beside Bredagh School
4493784/4420006/4536462.text: There is a field out in front of the school and there is a piece of rough ground in it.  It is said that it was used as a graveyard long ago.  It is a square piece of land along the fence of the field.The land round about it is cultivated but this piece is not.  To look at it one would think it was a small it was a small quarry.  It is all grown over with long grass and briars.It is about two miles from Moville.  There is no trace of a church in it.  The graves cannot be seen either.  The little graveyard is in Bredagh Glen, Moville.

4493778/4419565/4536848.title: Old Churchyards
4493778/4419565/4536848.text:
There is one churchyard in the townland of Cooley. It is not in use now. The churchyard is square and slopes towards the South-East. There was a church in the graveyard and it now stands in ruins. The churchyard is not level. There are some old tombs in it and a nun is buried there. There is one old cross outside the walls of the graveyard. Cooley Cross is made of stone and is ornamented. There are five holes in the cross. One round one is on the top and four semi-circles in the centre of the cross. If anybody puts a stone through the top of the hole and wishes they will get their wish. One night the top of Cooley Cross was knocked down and the next morning it was back in its right place again. Cooley Cross is the same length under the ground as it is above it. There are no trees growing in Clooney graveyard. People are buried inside the ruins of the Church. The people now are buried at whatever parish they belong to.Cooley Church belonged to the Catholics from the beginning. The Protestants had no church so the Catholics let the Protestants have the church in the evening and the Catholics used it in the morning. That is
(continues on next page)

4493778/4419577/4536872.title: Old Churchyards
4493778/4419577/4536872.text:
There is one churchyard in the townland of Cooley. It is not in use now. This churchyard contains many very old tombstones. Outside the gate stands a cross. It is said that this cross was put there by St. Patrick. This cross is made of stone cut out of rock. There are not any trees growing in it. Catholics and Protestants are buried in this churchyard and just underneath the gate there is a negro sailor buried. He died on a ship that came into Lough Foyle and no one knew what religion he belonged to that is why he was buried at the gate. At that time there was no one buried in it but Catholics. There was a monastry built in this graveyard. The Danes burned this monastry and killed the monks except one who escaped. This graveyard is sloping in an easterly direction. There are two churchyards in our Parish. Their names are Drung and Iskaheen. These churchyards are still in use. They do not contain any very old tombstones. Cooley graveyard contains very very old tombstones the oldest one is said to be that of St. Finian. There are two priests buried in this graveyard. One of them was parish priest of Moville for thirty five years. Some of the tombstones are ornamented. This
(continues on next page)

4493792/4421359/4536932.title: The Old Graveyards
4493792/4421359/4536932.text: The Old GraveyardsIn this parish there is a graveyard called Kilblaney it is almost entirely forgotten although in living memory burials have taken place there. It is situated on a rocky eminence and only the huge slabs of stone to tell anyone of its formers use.No boundary walls sorround it and the Atlantic washed its rocky base. Cattle and sheep graze over it and although on the main road to Inishowen Head a tourist resort. It lies up on this eminence unnoticedA noted Bishop once gave his opinion that a church must have existed there long before any present day places of worship existed.

4493780/4419943/4537959.title: On Old Graveyards
4493780/4419943/4537959.text:
On old graveyards.There are six recognized graveyards in this parish. There is one at Drung and on at Iskaheen. These tow are Catholic grave-yards. Then there are Protestant grave-yards situated in Greenbank, Redcastle, Muff, and one at Knowhead. There are two old graveyards in this parish too, and infant burial ground at Carrowkeel, and another old graveyard in the Clunelly district. These grave-yards are all in use except the infant burial ground and the grave-yard in Clunelly. Some of these are round in shape and there are churches within them except in the two disused ones. There is a new chapel at Drung and there are the ruins of an old chapel there too. The graveyard at Drung is not level but sloping eastwards. There are some very big tombstones and monuments in the graveyard at Iskaheen. There are people buried within the ruins of the old Chapel at Drung, but there is nobody being buried there now. There is no person in this district now who remembers burials to take place in the graveyard at Clunelly or in the
(continues on next page)

4493786/4420337/4537970.title: A Funny Story
4493786/4420337/4537970.text:
A Funny Story.Once upon a time a man was going from Donegal to Dublin and he had a donkey with him. He asked the guard where would he put the donkey. The guard said to put him in behind, but instead of putting him in the van the man tied him to the end of the last carriage. When the train was a while on its journey the man asked a passenger in the compartment at what rate the train was going "About forty miles an hour," was the  answer. By Jingo, paddy is fairly stepping it now," says the man.



The local Graveyards.There are three churchyards in the parish, Ballinacreagh churchyard, Ballybrack churchyard and Cooley churchyard. Ballinacreagh
(continues on next page)

4493781/4419721/4538246.title: Old Graveyards
4493781/4419721/4538246.text:
There are a few old graveyards in this locality and I will describe as fully as I can all about this particular one.On the Ballyargus side of the Drung river there is an old graveyard to be found in a farm belonging to Willie Duffy. There is a rectangular shaped field containing about three acres, and it is in this field, about one hundred and fifty yards from the river, and about the same distance from the Ballyargus road or to tell its position in a few roads it lies exactly in the centre of the field.The graveyard itself, containing about half a rood, is an exact square, each side being about thirty yards. it is enclosed by a small ditch about three feet high. The graveyard which was used for burying children is very rocky ground. Some of these rocks are flat, level pieces, of stone about five feet long,
(continues on next page)

4493781/4419814/4538302.title: The Local Graveyards
4493781/4419814/4538302.text:
There are four graveyards in this parish, namely- the graveyard attached to St. Columba's R.C. Church, Drung ; the Protestant graveyard attached to Redcastle Parish Church ; the graveyard attached to St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Iskaheen ; and the Presbyterian graveyard attached to the Presbyterian Church at Greenbank. ( Greenbank is a place along the main Derry-Moville road, a short distance above Quigley's Point.The most convenient of graveyards to this district is the one attached to St. Columba's Catholic Church, which is adjacent to Drung National School.As a matter of fact there are three graveyards surrounding the church,- the lower or  "old" graveyard, the middle graveyard, and the upper or      " new" graveyard- but all are combined or united in one by a neat stone wall. Most of the graves have "tombstones" or "headstones" as they are locally called; any of the graves that have no "headstones", have a stone placed at the head and feet, to mark its position.
(continues on next page)

4493807/4423129/4538512.title: Old Graveyards
4493807/4423129/4538512.text: (1) There is an old graveyard in Colhoun's field of Ballelaghan about 1 1/2 mile from Malin town.  The mounds of the old graves are still to be seen.  Thomas Fulton (about 80 years) of Ballelaghan remembers people being buried there.(2) An old graveyard was in the middle of a field in the Isle of Doagh.  The owners of the field thought it a pity to waste this ground so they commenced to dig it up.A voice from the ground warned them not to continue, but they refused to be advised.The hair fell from both their heads and they were bald till the day they died.

4493811/4422818/4538623.title: Old Graveyards
4493811/4422818/4538623.text: There are three old graveyards in our parish.  There is one in Templemoyle, one in Drumcarbit and one in Malin Head.The one in Drumcarbit was used for burying children that were not baptised.  The graveyard in Templemoyle was not used since the year 1819.The last person buried in it was a man. This is the inscription on his grave: -James McGuinessDied Jan 25 1819Age fifty yearsThe people of Malin Head did not know about the graveyard in their district until one day the man in which whose farm the graveyard was began to plough the plot.He at once started to turn up bones of human beings.  He then understood that this must be an old graveyard and he filled it up again.None of these graveyards are in use now.

4493809/4422962/4538964.title: Local Graveyards
4493809/4422962/4538964.text: There are four graveyards in use in this parish.  These are attached to Lagg Roman Catholic Church, Lagg Presbyterian Church, Malin Church and Aughaclay Roman Catholic Church.There is a little private cemetery in the plantation near Malin.  Here the ancestors of the Harvey family are buried.The graveyard at Lagg Roman Catholic Church is on a slope overlooking the sea.  There are no trees near it but there are sandbanks all round it.Lagg Presbyterian graveyard is level.  There are no trees near it.  Malin Church is level.  There are large trees growing round it one of them a beautiful copper beech.Aughaclay graveyard is on a slope but there are no trees growing near it.

4493809/4422963/4538965.title: Local Graveyards
4493809/4422963/4538965.text: There are four graveyards in this district.  Two of them are situated at Lagg and one in Malin and one in Templemoyle.  One of the graveyards at Lagg and the one in Templemoyle belong to the Roman Catholic Church.  The other in Lagg is a Presbyterian one and the one in Malin is Church of Ireland.There is an old graveyard in Balleelaghan but it is not now in use.  There are no crosses or headstones in it.  It was said that long ago people across from the island were buried there.  The Roman Catholic graveyard in Lagg is situated on the slope of a hill, looking over the sea, and is surrounded by sandbanks on which bent grows.  The Presbyterian graveyard is below sea level and often in the winter the sea comes in and it becomes flooded.The Church of Ireland graveyard is square and flat with many crosses and has many beautiful trees growing in it.The other Roman Catholic graveyard is situated at the bottom of a hill and has some trees growing near to it also.

4493809/4422964/4538966.title: Local Graveyards
4493809/4422964/4538966.text: There are six graveyards in this district.  There are two graveyards at Lagg, a Roman Catholic graveyard and a Presbyterian graveyard.At the Roman Catholic graveyard we find many very old tombs.The graveyard slopes to the south west. At Malin we find two Protestant graveyards.  One of these is a private cemetery belonging to the Harvey family.  A vault adjoins this cemetery.  It stands on a slope facing the east.Above Malin Town, there is still the remains of an old graveyard in which English soldiers called the "White Boys" are supposed to be buried.There is a legend connected with this burial ground.No one is supposed to work this part and one time a man began to dig up this graveyard and his spade stuck fast and he was unable to pull it up again.

4493809/4422965/4538967.title: Local Graveyards
4493809/4422965/4538967.text: There are three graveyards in this district.  One of them is situated in Malin Town.  It belongs to the Church of Ireland.  The graveyard is flat and low-lying.  There are many nice tombs in it.The other two are situated about three and a half miles further on towards Malin Head.  One of these is at the Roman Catholic Church.  This graveyard slopes to the south-west and is situated on the side of a hill.  The graveyard is big and part of it very old.The Presbyterian Church graveyard is below sea level.It is said that during the persecution when Presbyterians were not allowed to build churches, this site was granted by the landlord who was Church of Ireland.  He was anxious to supply their needs but afraid to incur displeasure and so he gave them a site below sea level.In the winter the tide often lashes in and part of the graveyard is submerged for a time.

4493796/4421493/4540276.title: Graveyards
4493796/4421493/4540276.text:
In the parish of Clonmany there are only three old graveyards in which people were buried long ago. Here and there through fields there are heaps of stones and it is supposed that people were buried in these places long ago. On the top of Raitlin [?] there is a heap of stones and stone stairs going up to the top of the heap. It was supposed that on the top of this that Queen Maeve [?] used to hold council and she is buried underneath it. One of these grave-yards outside the village of Clonmany is called Saint Mary's graveyard. The second is at Straid named Colmcille's and the third is at Binion. In the Clonmany graveyard people are buried to the present day. In the other two people have not been buried for a good many years. All these graveyards are about one acre in area and are all heights and hollows. In the Clonmany graveyard the church is still standing and Mass is celebrated in it. In the other graveyards nothing remains but a mass of ruin. At the Straid graveyard a small cellar is still to be seen where the people used to make malt long ago.
(continues on next page)

4493718/4413951/4548385.title: The Old Graveyards
4493718/4413951/4548385.text:
The Old Graveyards.There are nine graveyards in the parish, There is one in Monellan, one at the Crossroads, two in Donaghmore, one in Catlefinn, one in the Alt, one in Carnone, one in Seaighoneill, and one in Churchminster.These churchyards are all still in use and are square in shape. There is church inside all the graveyards except Churchminster. Here the ruins of a church are still to be seen. Some of the graveyards are level and some are sloped. There are no trees growing in the graveyards unless the small trees that people planted at the graveyard.The churchyards contain very old tombs, and crosses, and monuments, for years back. Some of the crosses are plain and others are ornamented. In
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354531/4551475.title: The Old Graveyards
4427887/4354531/4551475.text:
There are three churchyards in the parish.  Their names are Barnacarroll, Balllinamal and Kilcolman.  These church-yards are situated in Barnacarroll Ballinasmal and Kilcolman.  These church-yards are still in use.  They are not round in shape.There is a church in ruins in Ballinasmal and in Kilcolman.  The church-yard of Barnacarroll has a hill and slopes north.  There are trees in one of the church-yards.There are old tombs and crosses in these churchyards.  The crosses are made of wood and some of them are made of iron.  The
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354550/4551486.title: The Graveyards
4427887/4354550/4551486.text:
Graveyards in this parish.  They were three.  Their names are, Kilcolman, Barnacarroll, and Ballinasmal.Barnacarroll graveyard is situated in the village of Barncarroll, and Kilcolman graveyard is situated in the village of Kilcolman.All the graveyards are still in use.  There is a church in ruins in Kilcolman and there is also in Ballinasmal.In Barnacarroll there are three landlords buried in a little house.  There are shelves in it for coffins to be left on, and there an iron door in it and it is locked always.There are trees growing round all the churches.  The crosses are made of cement and stones.  The unbaptised children were buried in forts.
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354567/4551502.title: The Old Graveyards
4427887/4354567/4551502.text:
There are three graveyards in the parish.  There names are Banacarroll, Kilcolman, and Ballinasmal.  They are situated in the townlands of Kilcolman, Ballinasmal and Barnacarroll.  They are still in use.  None of the churchyards are round in shape.  There is a church in ruins in Kilcolman and in Ballinasmal.  One of the churchyards is level.  Some of them slope north. There are trees growing in one of them.  The churchyards contain some old tombs but not many.  The dates of them are not known.   The crosses are not ornamented.  Some of the crosses are made of wood and others of iron.  There are people buried within the ruins of the church.  There are not
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354575/4551510.title: The Old Graveyards
4427887/4354575/4551510.text:
There are three churchyards in this parish.  The names of them are Kilcolman, Barnacaroll and Ballinasmall.  Kilcolman is situated in the townland of Kilcolman.  Barnacarroll churchyard is situated in the townland of Barnacarroll.  Ballinasmall churchyared is situated in the townland of Ballinsmall.They are all still in use and none of them round in shape.  There is a churchyard in ruins in Kilcolman.  All the churchyards are level.  There are trees growing in Kilcolman graveyard.  The churchyards contain very old tombs and crosses.  The crosses are ornamented.  There are crosses made of wood and iron and some of them are made of cement.  There are people
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354585/4551525.title: The Old Graveyards
4427887/4354585/4551525.text:
There are three graveyards in this parish.  Barnacarroll graveyard, Kilcolman graveyard, and Ballinansmal graveyard.  These graveyards are in  use yet.  There are none of these graveyards round in shape.  There is a church in ruins in Kilcolman.  There is a little house in ruins in Barnacarroll where landlords where buried.  There are shelves and two coffins left on them.There are trees growing round Kilcolman graveyard.  In olden times unbaptised children were buried.  There are people buried in ruins.   Crosses are made of wood and iron.  There are not ane graveyards that is not in use in the parish.Families come
(continues on next page)

4562119/4561221/4570661.title: Díol agus Ceannacht
4562119/4561221/4570661.text:
An Reilig Tá da reilg san bparáiste seo. Tá ceann i leacaigh agus ceann eile i gCill Sgeach. Níor cuirtear aoine i gCill Sgeach. Leanbhaí a fuair bás gan a bheith baisthe is mó atá curtha ann. Tá an reilg seo i bhfiad istigh ón mbhóthair
(continues on next page)

4562119/4561222/4570662.title: An Reilig
4562119/4561222/4570662.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus ni theigheann na daoine isteach ann.Ta reilg an pharaiste sios ar mbothar leachaigh. Ta se timcheall leath-mhile no mar sin on seipeal. Cuirtear daoine o gach taobh den pharaiste ann agus ta go leor leacracha cuimhneachain ann freisin. Ta an reilg sin deantha mar croidhe agus ta sean teampaill in aice an reilge. Deirtear ma thuiteann duine ins an reilg go mbeadh cos tinn acha go deo agus go bhfhuigheadh se bas sul a rachaidh an bliadhian thart.



Ta dha reilig ins an bparaiste seo. Ta ceann acu
(continues on next page)

4562119/4561224/4570664.title: An Reilig
4562119/4561224/4570664.text:
(continued from previous page)
caillte san bparaiste curtha i reilge na paraiste.



Ta ceithre reilig sa bparaoiste seo. Siad na h-ainmneacha ata ortha na reilig Leacaigh, reilig Doiremaclochnaigh (Derrymacloughny), reilig Cill Sgeach agus lios na nGrainseach. Ni cuirtear daoine in aon cheann acu anois acht san ceann i Leacaigh agus uaireanta i gCill Sgeach. Ta cuma gan slacht ortha, mar ta neantogai is driosachai is gach
(continues on next page)

4562119/4561226/4570667.title: An Reilig
4562119/4561226/4570667.text:
(continued from previous page)
iasachta.



Bhi go leor sean-reiligi tar timcheall na h-aite seo fado ; bhi ceann i Leacaigh , ceann i Bhaile an Bhroin agus bhi ceann eile i Rathfaoi. Ta ait i MoinArd agus ta pairc mhor ann air a dtugtar lisin air agus cuirtear na paisti beaga a fuair bas gan baiste ann.Ta ceann eile i gCill Sgeach i bpairc mhor agus ta leacracha mora ann agus ta go leor crainnte ann fos. Bhi seipeal ann fado agus deirtear go bhfuil an talamh beannuighthe.Ta ait in aice le Tuaim agus bhi fear ag gearradh mona ann la amhain
(continues on next page)

4562119/4561227/4570673.title: An Reilig
4562119/4561227/4570673.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus fuair se fear marbh ann.



Bhi tri reiligi ins an bhparaoiste fado, ceann i Rath Faoi, agus ceann eile i mBhaile an Bhroin agus ceann i Leacaigh acht nil acht ceann amhain ann anois. Cuirtear na leanbhai a fuair bas gan bhaiste san reilig ata i Rath Faoi. Lisin a tugtar air. Ta fothrach sean teampaill i ngach ceann aca agus go leor crainnte san gceann ata i Rath Faoi.
(continues on next page)

4566064/4563728/4571651.title: An Reilig - Cilliaraorthan
4566064/4563728/4571651.text:
Tá dhá reilig sa paróiste, Cill-ar-Aorthann atá mar ainm ar an ceann fé leith seo. Tá sé leath-thaobh  (?) na Cille, ag an taoibh thoir dí. Tá sé cearnógach. Tá fothrach Cille i gceart lár dí - acht ní feidir aon duine atá beo a radh agus ní feidir aon tuairisg le faghail cé thoghadh í.Tá an reilig fanaidh. Gabhann an fanaidh thoir. Tá cuig is fichidh sean tuambaí ann. Tá cúma ceána  ar gach ceann acu. Tá siad go leir clúduighthe le cloc mór cearnógach, agus tá ainmneacha na  (?) sgriobhtha ar an gcloc seo. Tá cuid acu suas le dhá céad bliain.Cloc ÓrnáideachSan reilig seo tá cloc fé leith ag ceann uaige. Tá an cloc seo ceithre-orlaigh deag ar fhaid, agus dhá orlaigh i leitheadh.Tá cat le dhá ruball geárrtha amac as an gcloic seo, agus tá sceál faoi den sgríobhta le ceann de na buacaillí san leathanach eile de'n leabhar seo.Chuala mé sgéal ina thaoibh. Bhí triúr ag taistil na tíre uair. Cuireadar futha i dtig ar bun Ardán na Cille. Bhí ceann acu marbh ar maidin
(continues on next page)

4566078/4565193/4571796.title: An Reilig
4566078/4565193/4571796.text:
Tá tuairim is sé reiligí sa bparáiste againnn. Tá ceann i gCeathramha an Bhrúnaigh agus is "Lisín Dháithe" a tugtar air.  Tá ceann i gCillín agus "Reilig Chillín" a tugtar air.  Tugtar "Reilig Bhaile an Treasna" ar cheann eile.  "Teampall Shiubháin Ní Laighin", "Múr-Ros-Cham" agus "Reilig Mhionnluigh" a tugtar ar chin eile.  Cuirtear daoine i ngach ceann aca fós ach amháin i "dTeampall Shiubháin Ní Laighin".  Tá cuma dronuilleógach orra ar fad.Níl aon fhothrach ar bith in aice na reiligí ins an bparáiste seo againne, ach tá roinnt fothracha cóingaracha d'óibh.  Tuairim is ceithre chéad slat ó reilig Cheathramha an Bhrúnaigh tá fothracha de chaisleán na mBrúnach, dream a bhí in a gcómhnaidhe san áit sa seachtmhadh aois déag.Tá na reilige ar fad leibhéalta ach amháin go bhfuil roinnt clocha annseo agus annsiúd ionnta.  Níl aon chran nnó tor ionnta anois. Bhí cúpla ceann ann ach nuair a d'eirigh siad sean bhain na fir iad nuair bhí siad ghá nglanadh.  Tá roinnt sean-chroiseanna ann fós ach tá na daoine a'cur croiseanna móra cloiche agus ainmneacha na ndaoine atá caillte scríobhtha orra, ós cionn gach uaight.Bhíodh tuambaí i gcuid de na religí fadó agus bhíodh an duine caillte curtha isteach ionnta.
(continues on next page)

4566064/4563729/4571812.title: An Reilig - Cilliaraorthan
4566064/4563729/4571812.text:
(continued from previous page)
la ar na mbarach. D'imthigh an beirt eile. Sul ar éirig fear an tighe. Is amhlaidh a tháinig naire orra agus tháinigeadar ar ais arís. agus chuir siad é san áit ina b'fuil an reiligh anois. Cuirtear muintear na paróiste san áit ó shoin amach.



Tá reilig eile tuairim is dá míle ón reilig luaidthe thuas. Tugtar Craoibhreach bán mar ainm ar an reilig seo. Bíonn tuars naomhtha go dtí an reilig seoTá fortach cille i lár na reilige seoTháinig na Manaigh go dtí an áit seo ó Cluain-fuis nuair a bhí an monastear seo dúnta i m'aimesear an dermadh Enrí. Só Naomh Norber patrún na cille seo.Tá tuambha mór ansin istigh sa  chill i gcuimhne fir d'arbh ainm Búrca as Cluain. Tá dealbh an fhir seo clós na n-ard cille, Tuaim freisin.Tá Tobar naomhtha ann freisin, deirtear go raibh an tobar i dtaobh eile d'en reilig ar dtús
(continues on next page)

4562124/4561508/4571891.title: Graveyard
4562124/4561508/4571891.text: My graveyard is situated on the south of this parish. It is called Killmoylan. It is situated on a little hill and it is of a round shape.There are three tombs in my graveyard, they belong to the Blakes, the Bodkins and the Mc Cabes. The graveyard is full of graves but people are not buried in some of them now.There is a ruin in my graveyard, but there is only two walls standing and there is a priest and other people buried inside it.Long ago there were no children buried in Killmoylan but now children are buried in it the same as the grown up people. Before this the children were buried in a place called a cillín that is north of this school in the village of Ballinderry.

4566066/4563968/4571960.title: Old Graveyards
4566066/4563968/4571960.text:
Long ago tombstones were made in the form of large flags, which were left flat on the grave. It was usual for some token of the man’s business to be engraved on this flag such as a sheep crook on a herd’s, an anvil on a blacksmiths etc. In Kilbannon graveyard near Tuam you will see many examples of this custom. In this graveyard you will notice a bone engraved on the local bonesetters grave. The gentry had family vaults made in the form of houses which were built over the ground. This custom has been altered and they are now obliged to make the vaults under ground, only certain kinds of trees were let grow in the ground, ash being the most common. It was the general belief that the last person buried in the graveyard would have to watch it until the next person was buried there, so when two people died in the same locality there was a rush to the graveyard. Up to some time ago the local priest
(continues on next page)

4566066/4564017/4572001.title: Tuam Graveyard
4566066/4564017/4572001.text:
A graveyard is to be seen in Chapel lane. Many old celtic crosses can also be seen there. There are many other things to be seen there such as the floating coffins and the ruins of an old church. The coffins are nearly rotted now because the water rotted the wood. There is a little room built of stone in which is a tomb and it is under this room the coffins are to be seen through a square piece cut out of the stone. There is a tomb about four feet from the floating- coffins and it is said that it is from this tomb the coffins floated.On some of the tombstones many old Tuam characters can be seen. Inscriptions are written on the tombstones about people such as the Donnellons of Sylane and many others.This graveyard extends from
(continues on next page)

4566066/4564028/4572015.title: Creevagh Graveyard
4566066/4564028/4572015.text: There is a grayard on the Dublin Road called The Creevagh graveyard.There is a Blessed Well outside the graveyard.There is a stone house beside it and inside in the house.The head of Saint Brigid is shaped in stone.The Well it is said is decated to Saint Brigid.Monks lived there it is said but they were hunted in the Penal Times.

4566079/4565330/4572176.title: Graveyards
4566079/4565330/4572176.text: Graveyards:-There are four graveyards in this district - Forthill, New Cemetery, Dominican and Rahoon. The dead people are put in three of these but not in the Dominican which is only for priests. The Dominican graveyard is round; New Cemetery is square, Forthill is circular and Rahoon is square.There is the ruin of an ancient chapel in Forthill and people are not usually buried in this place. There is a slope running east in Forthill, running south in New Cemetery. Rahoon has a level graveyard and so has the Dominican Church. There are trees growing in the graveyards - yew trees or weeping willows. There is a large cross which is very old in the graveyard at Forthill. There is a large tree growing through one of the tombs in the Dominican graveyard.

4566070/4564369/4572444.title: Religious Stories
4566070/4564369/4572444.text:
(continued from previous page)

There are two graveyards in the parish of Kilgerrill. In one of the those graveyards there are the ruins of an old Church. The gate going into this graveyard is still to be seen there. There are carvings on most of the stones. there are four stones placed inside one of of the old windows
(continues on next page)

4566067/4564108/4572512.title: (no title)
4566067/4564108/4572512.text: There is a floating coffin in the Mall Garveyard. It is the burial place of an old king. There is about 14 feet of water under the coffin. There was also other thigs things found in the Mall Garaveyard by Mr Flaherty. He was caretaker and found swords and hatchets there.

4566067/4564120/4572534.title: The Old Churchyards up the Dublin Road and Other Roads
4566067/4564120/4572534.text: There is an old churchyard up the Dublin Rd. It is about four hundred years old. There is a lot of people buried in this old churchyard. There is a big wall around it. It is about ten feet high. You would not know it is a churchyard unless you inquired about it. The people that are buried in it were buried in it when the famine was on.

4569049/4566648/4573071.title: Local Graveyards
4569049/4566648/4573071.text:
There are four graveyards in the combined parishes of Kilconieran and Kilconickney:-1. Kilkonickney in the townland of Carramore2. Kilconieran in the townland of Kill, near the church.3. Lickerrig  in the townland of Leacarrow.4. Toalooban in the townland of Toalooban.All of these are very old but are still in use. In each of the graveyards are the ruins of an old church. There are some modern tombstones in the graveyards and there are many rectangular stone flags used as tombstones. Most of these are without inscriptions.Toalooban graveyard is circular in shape. The other three are rectangular.KILKONICKNEYThis graveyard appears to be the oldest of the four. The tombstones are irregular in shape and contain no inscriptions.The old church is completely in ruins, only portion of one gable wall standing - on the eastern end where the altar was. There are no graves North-west of the old church. The land is quite level. A new plot of field has been added to it in recent years.
(continues on next page)

4569050/4566861/4573466.title: Old Graveyards
4569050/4566861/4573466.text:
In the district where the Ganty school is situated there are two grave yards. Their names are Kilconieron and Lickerrig. They are almost in a straight line with each other though not on the same road or the same townland.The Kilconieron graveyard is situated in the townland of Kilconieron, parish of Carrowbane, and barony of Dunkelly. The Catholic Church of Kilconieron or "Kille" , as it is called locally, is beside this graveyard which is on the left side of the public road which runs from Garracloone to the main road which leads to the town of Athenry on the north and Loughrea on the south-east.This graveyard is still used for the
(continues on next page)

4569051/4566929/4573640.title: Old Graveyard
4569051/4566929/4573640.text: Not far from our house in Cannos land there is supposed to be an old graveyard. Long ago this graveyard was used for burying young children that died when born. All the children that died at Cannons, and at the neighbouring houses were buried there. There are still some small pointed stones jutting up out of the ground, and these stones are supposed to be the headstones of the little children.

4569055/4567456/4574697.title: Old Graveyards
4569055/4567456/4574697.text:
There are three graveyards in my parish. The names of them are the, Kilogileen graveyard, Ardnamóran graveyard. and the Kilora graveyard. Kilogileen graveyard is situated in the parish of Ballymana in the barony of Dunkellin. It is still in use. It is surrounded by a double stone wall. There is an old ruined church in it. The graveyard is sloped towards the south. There are ever green trees growing in it. The churchyard contains one tomb and many crosses. The crosses are dated on many places but they are invisable. The most
(continues on next page)

4569044/4566439/4574704.title: Graveyards
4569044/4566439/4574704.text:
Graveyards 3..6..38There are three graveyards in the parish of Oranmore and the names of them are the Ballinacourty graveyard,the Kilcaimin graveyard and the Oranmore graveyard.There are people buried in all these. The Ballinacourty graveyard is square and the Kilcaimin one and the Oranmore one are irregular in shape.In the Ballinacourty and Kilcaimin graveyards there are two old churches and the walls of them still stand. There is a Church in the Oranmore graveyard and it is still used. The Ballinacourty and the Kilcaimin graveyards are on the side of a hill and the Oranmore graveyard is on level land.There are no trees in the Ballinacourty and the Kilcaimin graveyards but there are some in the Oranmore graveyard.There are some tombs and crosses in the Oranmore and Ballinacourty graveyards but there are no tombs or
(continues on next page)

4569044/4566448/4574753.title: Graveyards
4569044/4566448/4574753.text:
There are three graveyard in this Parish and the names of them are Killeely, Killeenan, and Stradbally. There are many people buried in thes graveyards at the presnet day. The Killeely and Stradbally graveyards are square but the Killeenan graveyard is irregular in shape. In the Kileely and Killeenan graveyards there are two old churches and they are still to be seen but the Stradbally graveyard has only the remains of the church. The Stradbally graveyard is on a hill but the other two are on level land. There are many trees around the Killeenan graveyard but there are no trees around the Kileely and Stradbally graveyards. There are a good number of head-stones in these graveyards but there are more tomb-stomas then head-stones because long ago tomb-stones were used more than head-
(continues on next page)

4569054/4567210/4575092.title: Seanreiligí
4569054/4567210/4575092.text:
In 1691 when Cromwell's army was passing through Kilchreest after the battle of Aughrin  on its way to Limerick he knocked every church that came his way, and to this day the ruins can be seen to tell the tale of the tyranny of Cromwell and his armies. When the people heard of the approach of the army, they removed the bell to a place of safety, and the old people used to say it was buried in the callow at the back of the village.This churchyard occupies a very romantic site, on a little eminence to the west of the village, it is the first scene that comes into view from all directions crom crowned by the ruins of the old church and beautiful trees, it is greatly admired by strangers. It is a thickly peopled burned burial ground, since the time of the Roxboro Factory which turned out all sorts of wood
(continues on next page)

There is an old church-yard in Carramore it is called Teampull church-yard. There is people buried there still but not many. It is a very small church-yard, and there are not many people buried there now, the headstones are very small over the (th) graves.There is also an old church-yard in Suide Finn. It is inside the road. There is a (small) wall around it, and it is built the shape of a coffin. There are not many people buried there now. It is near Suide Finn Hill and some people say that it was in that grave that Daly was buried. That grave-yard was there for people of Suide Finn. They used have to repair it themselves. When the
(continues on next page)

There is a churchyard in Kilchrest where the people of the parish are buried. There was an old church there and Cromwell knocked it and the ruins are still there. There is a small graveyard in Ballacurra where young children are buried. There are some headstones there also. It is on the left hand side of the road in a large field. There is a small churchyard in Gortnamona, Kilchrest, where young children are buried. It is situated in a big field on the West side of Gortnamona.

4569054/4567215/4575095.title: Seanreiligí
4569054/4567215/4575095.text:
In this district there is not many churchyards which are not being still used, they are mostly "cills" where young children who died before they are baptised were buried. The following are some of the "cills" which are in the district. Ballinagarry, in brucán, in Coscarrig near the town of Loughrea. Also one near St. Colmcille's well. It is also said that there is one in Mr. Smith's sandpit where the monks of St. Colmcille's monastery were interred.



There are no churchyards in this district that have not been in use, but there are remains of old ones to be seen. The following are names of places where they are to be seen. Kilaspic: There was a churchyard

4569060/4567671/4583472.title: Old Graveyards in the District
4569060/4567671/4583472.text:
There are a few old graveyards in the district. There is one in Dunmore and one in Addrigoole, one in Kiltevna and one in Gortnagrawn. There was a Church near every one of them.The old graveyard in Dunmore is sloping towards the south. They bury people in it yet but only four five more people has to be

4569060/4567681/4583486.title: Seanreiligí
4569060/4567681/4583486.text:
Tuairim seact reilig atá í bparroiste i nDún-mór Ceann í gCill í Suibhne ceann í "Idir dá gabhail'' dá cheann i nDún-mór ceann í "Ceallunaigh''  ceann í "Cloc ó Ciáran agus ceann í Srule.Cuirtear leanbhaí í gCeallunaigh í Srule agus í gCloch ó Ciárán agus cuirtear daonibh anseo ins na reiligí eile. Tá cuma cearnógach ar gach ceann acu. Tá fothrach an tsean cille í  gceill í-Suibhne ins an reilig. Tóg Pádhraig Náomhtha An Sean-Cill sin nuair a tháinig sé annseo ar dtús.

no seats in it. Not many people are living now that were going to that school. Jim Quirke and Michael Gorman were going to that school.Mr. John Mahoney was the teacher's name. The school children would have to bring a penny everyday and two sods of turf that was the pay the teacher was getting.He had a small garden of potatoes out side the school. The school boys would have to sow that garden, and to weed it. He had a pig also, and the boys would have to dig the potatoes and to wash them for the pig.



There is a church-yard in Kilchreest. It was there that the old church was long ago. It was knocked
(continues on next page)

4583281/4576239/4583880.title: Old Graveyards
4583281/4576239/4583880.text:
There are many graveyards in this parish and in most parishes we find some.       The nearest graveyard from this school is Chapelfinerty. It is situated in the parish of Ahascragh and it is now a very old one. It is shaped like a coffin and it contains many old crosses and monuments.      There is an old cave at the back of this graveyard and it is always filled with water. Some say this water will never boil and attempts have been made which have proved unsuccessful. Long ago there was a chapel in Chapelfinerty but there are no traces of it to-day.      Beside the Caltra Church in the townland of Caltra there is another graveyard and it is supposed to be one of the oldest in the parish.      It is a custom with many people who go away to come back to their native graveyard to be buried with their ancestors even though the place may be many miles away.      Unbaptised children are not buried in consecrated ground but are instead buried in an isolated spot.
(continues on next page)

4583295/4577331/4585747.title: The Old Graveyards  - Lisín
4583295/4577331/4585747.text: Lisheen in this parish is a burial ground for children. It is situated beside the Railway about a quarter of a mile East of Gort, in the land of Mr Farrell. It is approached by a narrow boreen, overgrown with briars and bushes, at the left hand side of the Railway station.The burial ground is on a hill, and slopes West towards the river at Kininche. It is surrounded by a low wall on three sides now overgrown with bushes. The Railway wall forms the boundary on the fourth side.At the left-hand side as you go in there is a tunnel. Long ago some of the older boys of the town now had a bad habit of "scheming" from school. A few of them one day "schemed" school and set out to explore the tunnel. They found it at first very dry but after a time they could see the water in front of them.They thought they were as far as Coole Lake and they hastened back.

4583295/4577332/4585748.title: The Old Graveyards - Kiltartan
4583295/4577332/4585748.text: About forty yards from Kiltartan church is the graveyard in which the dead of the parish are buried. In the middle of the graveyard there is the ruins of an old church, known as St. Altiacta's church. It is now covered with ivy both on the outside and inside. There are many graves in the old church. There are boards of coffins left beside the wall. Once a person lifted them up and immediately he got sick. There are many old graves in the graveyard, but most of them are made of limestone and cement. One head-stone dates back to a hundred and seventy-five years.

4583296/4577395/4585916.text:

4569070/4568886/4586451.title: Reilig
4569070/4568886/4586451.text: Cúpla mile nó mar sin ó'n aith in a bhfuilim in mo chomhnuidh tá áit dar b'ainm (Kilcloonach) in a bhfuil roilig. Tá sé suidhte ar an taobh cle de'n bótar (Kilcloonac) nuair a bhíodh duine ag dul  go Tuaim agus tá tuairm acra amháin ann. Ta cumha cearnóga air agus bhí an cuid is mó de's na daoine a fuair bhas ins an gceanntar seo curtha ann. Nior cur siad na paiste gan baisteá ann mar ins liseanna chuireadh siad. I lár an roilig tá sórt uaigh agus tá cnámha le feiceal istigh ann.  Tá sean fotaracha caisléan agus sean fotracha seipéal le feicheal in aice an roilig agus tá umar uisce beannuighthe ins an aith a raibh an seipéal.Stiopháin Mach Chinnéide Tonmhaoghal a innis dom é

4583271/4575437/4586511.title: An Reilig
4583271/4575437/4586511.text:
There are three graveyards in the parish. There is one in Kilconly, and two in Kilbannon. People are buried in two of them yet. They are shaped square. The are level. Trees grow in them. There are old tombs and old crosses in them. There is an unused graveyard in Kilbannon. There is an old ruin of a chapel in Kilbannon  There are people buried in the ruin. There is a story relating how the Kilconly grave yard was made. The time of the famine people were buried in  the fields. One time people were burying a man and the corpse was brought in a gennit cart.  While the people were digging the grave the gennit ran away. he did not stop until he came to Kilconly
(continues on next page)

4583307/4578248/4586761.title: Fairs in Gort in Ancient Times
4583307/4578248/4586761.text:
(continued from previous page)
man were arrested. At the present day the people return to their homes in an orderly fashion and it is very seldom we see a good fight between the tinkers.



In Beagh about two and a half miles from Gort, there is a graveyard, and the ruins of an old church are to be seen there. It is supposed to be the oldest graveyard in Ireland. In the penal days when the priests were not allowed to say mass, a small church was erected in the graveyard because that place was out of the way of the English soldiers. When the penal days were over, the church and graveyard were made bigger. There is still in the church a holy water font. There are
(continues on next page)

4583299/4577600/4586961.title: The Local Graveyards
4583299/4577600/4586961.text: There are graveyards in my district. There are three graveyards in Shanaglish, one in Newtown, one in Caherbroder and one in Derryowen. There is one graveyard in Shanaglish and there are no people buried there now. The one in Newtown is called the "Killin" and all unbaptized children are buried there. There is another graveyard like the one I spoke of in Caherbroder and unbaptized children are buried there also. It lies near a big fort or Dún called Broder's fort. The one in Derryowen is in de Blaquire's land and there are but two people there. There are two tomb-stones to mark their graves. The two persons were Mr and Mrs Lobdill two Protestant people who died of famine. There is another graveyard below the town of Gort. The graveyard is called Bully's Acre. The reason it is called

4569070/4569034/4587052.title: Graveyards
4569070/4569034/4587052.text:
There is a graveyard in almost every district.  There us one in Kilgevrin.  It is only a few years made.  It is at the (east) west side of the village and on the north side of the river Clare.  When the enginer came.  There was a big crowd before him.  He picked out the strongest men and put them working in the place he had marked out for the graveyard.  There was five pounds offered to the first man who would dig the first sod in it.  One man by the name of Tommy Glynn said he would and he was the first man that was buried in it.  When a person would die and be buried.  It is said that person would be the watch over the graveyard until another one is buried in it.  There are
(continues on next page)

4583289/4576829/4587075.title: Old Churchyards
4583289/4576829/4587075.text: There are three churchyards in the parish.One in Killyan, one in Rushestown and one in Cloonkeen. They are oblong in shape. There is not a ruined church in the churchyard. They are not level. The Killyan churchyard slopes to the south and Rushestown slopes west. There are trees and furze growing in the churchyards. There are crosses in Killyan churchyard. The crosses are not made of wood or iron they are made of stone. People are buried within the churchyards.Unbaptised children are buried in Rushestown and Cloonkeen churchyards. They are not called any special name. They are still used. There are no traditions or stories connected with them. Certain peple use church yards in other parishes.

4583289/4576830/4587076.title: Churchyards
4583289/4576830/4587076.text: There are three churchyards in the parish. The parish churchyard is in Killyan, about two miles from this school. There are two children's graveyards, one of those is in a field which belongs to Brian Crehan of Rushestown, the other is in a field which belongs to Mrs. Lawless of Cloonkeen, it is about a mile and a half from here. The churchyards are oblong. All are still in use. The one which is in Killyan slopes to the south. The graveyard in Brian Crehan's field slopes to the west. Thare are no churches or ruins in them. Briars and furzes grow in the churchyards.The parish churchyard contains crosses of stone but not of wood. Unbaptised children were buried in the childrens graveyards.Local families often use other graveyards. The Killroran graveyard in the parish of Ballygar is the most frequently used by people of this parish.

4583289/4576831/4587077.title: Churchyards
4583289/4576831/4587077.text: There are two Churchyards in the parish. One in Kilyan the parish Churchyard, and the other a childrens graveyard is in a field owned by Brian Creahan in the Village of Rushestown. They are still used.There is not ruined or otherwise in any of the Churchyards. They are not level. The Kilyan Churchyard slopes to the South and the Rushestown to the North. There are trees growing in them. The Kilyan Churchyard contains old crosses and these are made of stone. There are no disused Churchyards in the parish.Unbaptised children are buried in the childrens graveyards. They are still used. There are not stories or tales connected with the graveyards in this parish. Certain people use graveyards in other parishes.

4583333/4580475/4587206.title: The Old Graveyards
4583333/4580475/4587206.text: The Old GraveyardsThere are six graveyards in the parish of Eyrecourt.  Three of these are still in use - Clonfert, Meelick and Doone.  The three not in use are - Lisfinney, "Balloons" and an old graveyard in the Eyrecourt castle grounds.The Clonfert graveyard is part of the old Cathedral grounds.  Both Protestants and Catholics are buried here.  It is said that St. Brendan is buried in these grounds.  No monument marks the place.  However, people point to a flat oblong stone which is supposed to cover St. Brendan's grave.  The inscription on this stone is worn off so that nothing can be now learned from it.  But there is a curious story told in connection with this grave.  This story has been handed down from father to son for generations.  It is said that a cat jumped from the top of the Church steeple on to this stone.  The track of the cat's four paws can be seen on it to this day.   People firmly believe that St. Brendan's body lies buried here.
4583333/4580475/4587206.school_info: School: An Clochar, Dún an Ochta

4583307/4578269/4587354.title: (no title)
4583307/4578269/4587354.text: In the middle of Derrybrien graveyard there is a big rock and on it are two holes which are the prints of Saint Patrick's two knees. One hole is bigger than the other because it is said one of Saint Patrick's knees was swollen when he knelt there. It is believed that people who do rounds and pray at this rock are cured of swollen feet.
4583307/4578269/4587354.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Gort Inse Guaire

4583329/4580178/4587555.title: The Old Graveyard
4583329/4580178/4587555.text: The Old Grave Yard9 - 9 -'38There is one graveyard in my parish.  Its name is Abbey and it is situated in Rogerstown. It is still in use, the graveyard is square in shape.  There is a protestant church in it.The graveyard is level, there are a lot of old tombs and crosses to be seen there.  The crosses are made of iron. People were buried within the ruins of the wall.  Unbaptised children were formerly buried in Lisheens, this place is not used now.James Burke,Kilaltenagh,Banagher,Offaly.Material obtained from my father and mother.

4583337/4580832/4587828.title: Graveyards
4583337/4580832/4587828.text: GraveyardsThere are two graveyards in the parish of Kiltormer.  One is a Catholic graveyard and the other is a Protestant one.  They are a good distance apart.  The Protestant one is round in shape.  Trees grow inside the wall.  There is a small hill in it. Peope are still buried there.  An old church stands in it also.  The catholic one is at the back of the school.  It is round in shape.  Yew trees grow in it.  Some of the people of the parish are not buried in it.  They have burial places in other parishes.  Long ago there was an old church in it.  No ruins of the church are to be seen above the ground, but when people are making graves they dig up some of the stones.  Wooden crosses are not to be found there but people get small iron crosses made at the forge and put them at the heads of the graves.  There are no tombs in it.Patrick Tierney, Ballydonagh, Kiltormer, Ballinasloe.

4583316/4579022/4587944.title: Ballinakill Parish Cemeteries
4583316/4579022/4587944.text:
There are six old graveyards in the parish of Ballinakill.  they are in the following districts.  Ballinakill, Curra, Derrybrien, Drim, Lagoo and Marblehill.The three first mentioned, are used for burials presently, while the others are disused.  About forty years ago, Fr. Larkin condemned the latter, saying that all children should and would in future be buried in consecrated ground.  The farmers who own the fields in which these were buried, plans were never to meddle with them, or have tilled for crops.The graveyard of Ballinakill is situated on the slope of a sandy hill, facing southwards, about four hundred yards from the parochial church. Nearly all the headstones are of cement, and not one is known to bear any old date.  Over the few infants or or bigger children, an iron or wooden cross is there to mark their memory.  In this cemetery, the ruined wall of an old chapel is visible.  Outside, and quite near the wall is an old tomb, which is rectangular in shape, and made of stone.  It is commonly said that the Burke family, the descendants of the landlords of Marblehill are interred there.  The corpses were carried to the tomb and the slab drawn out and the coffin was placed on a underground shelf.  Then the big
(continues on next page)

4583317/4579100/4588089.title: The Graveyards in the Parish
4583317/4579100/4588089.text:
There are three graveyards in this parish namely Woodford Gurthaganna and Douras.  These three graveyards are situated in the parish of Ballinakill and Barony of Leitrim.  Some of the familie in this locality are not buried in any of those graveyards.  The Hayes and the Cleary families are buried at Clonrush, Whitegate, Co. Clare.  The Killeen the Brogan the Torpey and the Sammon families are buried in Mynoe Scariff County Clare.  The Goonan the Hickey and the McNamara families are buried in the Holy Island Mountshannon co Clare.  There are the remains of seven churches in the Holy Island an there is a round tower also.  There is a children's burial ground at the Eastern side of this village in Edward Hickey's field.  The local families still use the graveyards in which their ancestors
(continues on next page)

4583339/4580989/4591290.title: Graveyards
4583339/4580989/4591290.text:
In this parish of Lickmolassey, there are four graveyards still in use.  One is situated on the top of a hill about two miles from the town of Portumna in a townland called "Cill na Bruinn Óg".   This burial place is round in shape and is surrounded by high walls covered with ivy.  It is planted with trees.  Another name by which this graveyard is knows is Killmallinog.  It contains the ruins of an old monastery.  Another graveyard is to be seen in a townland called Lickmolassey.  This resting place of the dead is called Church Hill.  St. Molass came here and built a church and school here in the 5th century.  The ruins are still to be seen.  This graveyard is round in shape and is covered with tall pine trees, which can be seen for miles around, because this place is very much elevated.Around St. Brigid's church, in the centre of the town, we have another cemetery.  It's very old and in order to close it up; only people over 70 years of age are buried there.  The most remarkable thing about it is a vault containing the remains of Mrs Miller
(continues on next page)

4583352/4582154/4591446.title: Ballybroder Castle
4583352/4582154/4591446.text:
(continued from previous page)
ground passage leading from the castle out towards the fort Danesfort which is quite near it. The entrance to this passage is blocked up now.



On the end of this farm there is also an old graveyard which was erected by the Burke's of Ballybroder about a hundred years ago or more. All the Burke's are buried in it, namely:John Burke - died 28th Feb 1905 - aged 61 years. Patrick H Burke - died 15th Feb 1870Anne Burke - mother of Patrick H Burkeno date given. Oliver Burke - died 26th August 1890 - 32Ida Burke - died 12th June 1913 - 40 yrs. This graveyard is very small. It is only about 22ft broad by 48ft long.

4583310/4578481/4591539.title: Description of an Old Disused Graveyard
4583310/4578481/4591539.text:
The graveyard has been in existence for generations.  The most that were buried there were.  It is said that a priest was buried there also.  There is one to be seen there also.  It is about thirty years ago since a person was buried there.  And there is light often seen there.  There was never a church built on that ground but there was a school built near it.this ground was never consecrated. It is called Killahaun graveyard there wer'nt much grown up people buried there.  It was appointed for children who were born dead or died before baptism.There is a graveyard situated about 2 1/2 miles from Woodford.  The time of Cromwell all the people were driven out of their houses and had to seek shelter in the west of Galway.  When the people came they had no means of travelling so when the people they were buried in the first handy place the met.  In this unconsecrated ground there are six of seven unbaptised children buried there.  There is a priest's father buried there.  And there are four or five adults
(continues on next page)

4583311/4578592/4591658.title: Graveyards
4583311/4578592/4591658.text: There are three graveyards in this parish.  They are in Douras, Woodford and Gurthanna.  They are all still in use. Gurthanna is round in shape.  There is no church in any of them.  They are all level.  There are yew trees in Douras. There is a churchyard in Athanass for unbaptised children to be buried.   It is said that a man died during the famine and was buried in this graveyard.It is also said that a bell rings in Douras graveyard.Local families still use certain graveyards though they are much further away than the parish graveyard.Every Graveyard is facing the rising son.All the crosses are made of iron.

4583352/4582210/4591847.title: Graveyards
4583352/4582210/4591847.text: I live in the parish of Loughrea, there are three graveyards in it, namely "Garra Bridge." St. Brendan;s, and the Abbey graveyard. These graveyards are still in use. There is also an old graveyard on the Ballybrodert farm but it is not used now. This graveyard is square and on the side of a hill, sloping towards the East. It is surrounded by a four foot wall, and entered through a small iron gate, and there are palm trees growing in it. The graves are surrounded by iron railings and heavy stone work richly inscribed surmounts each grave.

4583294/4577246/4592624.title: (no title)
4583294/4577246/4592624.text: In Killeroran cemetery there is a memorial in the form of a round tower, about a hundred feet high to perpetuate the memory of Denis H. Kelly, Landlord of Aughrane to whom reference is made in this book. A slab embedded in the tower about twelve feet from the ground bears the following inscription:Dhonnachadh Anrí Uí Cheallaighba Taoiseach éDio Chraobh na ScrínRitheann Uí MháineDered doi Chloinsein Éirinn.do éag séBealtaine  7  1877(Above was transcribed by me from inside back cover of note book. C. Báiread.)

4583347/4581620/4592727.title: An Old Graveyard
4583347/4581620/4592727.text: An Old GraveyardNot far from our house in Mahoney's land there is supposed to be an old graveyard.  Long ago this graveyard was used for burying young children that died without Baptism.  All the unbaptised children that died at Mahoneys and at the neighbouring houses were buried there.  There are still some small pointed stones jutting up out of the ground and these stones are supposed to be the headstones of the little children.Collected by:- Mary Donohoe, Ballyyara, Bullaun.From:- My Grandmother.  Same address.  On the 19th Nov 1937 age 80.

4583347/4581622/4592730.title: Turoe Stone (Local Tradition)
4583347/4581622/4592730.text:
Turoe Stone (Local Tradition)There is a local tradition that this stone once occupied a site other than that on which it now stands. It was said that up to about eighty years ago it stood at a rath near by known as the rath Feerwore. Some years ago Patrick Lyons who had been employed by the late Mr Dolphin of Turoe for 40 years a herd pointed out the exact spot was about 10 yards to the west of the rath called Feerwore where the stone once stood. Excavation were made there and some animal remains together with a cist were found. The contents of the cist are supposed to have been human remains indicating cremation and the animal remains a funeral feast.E. J Moynihan, Bullaun, Loughrea on the 26th Nov 1937.From Tom Lyons, grandson of the above mentioned Patrick Lyons, Bullaun age 48.



Old GraveyardOutside Edward Blakes door there is an old graveyard.  Mr. Blakes two sons were buried there and all the little children who died without Baptism or after getting it in the neighbouring villages were buried there.  All the little graves were railed in.  Got by:- Patrick Flannery, Ballykeerin, Bullaun.From:- My Uncle Patrick aged 64.  Same Address on the 6th Dec 1937.

4583319/4579229/4592899.title: Story of a Graveyard
4583319/4579229/4592899.text: There is a old fort in Kilbrush.  It was used in olden times as a graveyard.  The old people say that during the bad times the people were dying, with the hunger, that they had to be buried in this old fort. There is a lot of small trees growing in it and no one ever cuts them.  They say it would not be lucky for them.  Often people coming home late at night from wakes heard very strange noises there like a lot of people crying.The people don't like passing it late at night as they are afraid and say it is haunted.

4583349/4581913/4606138.title: The Graveyard
4583349/4581913/4606138.text: Kilnadeema is the parish in which I live. There is one graveyard in it in which the people of this parish when they die are buried. The church is within in this graveyard. There is the ruins of another Church in the centre of this graveyard which are still to be seen. There are headstones and wooden crosses erected over all these graves which are very neatly kept. There is a small grave in this village in which children are buried when they die without been baptized. Many people when they travel near this grave at late hour of the night hear crying.

4583350/4582049/4606249.title: Graveyards
4583350/4582049/4606249.text:
There are two graves in our parish one in Kilteshill and the other in Kilnadeema.  Kilteshill means the church of the gospel.  There was a college there some years ago.  When Cromwells soldiers came to Ireland the knocked it.  There are people buried there yet.  It is square the graveyard is in Kilteshill.  It is a fairly large graveyard.  There are people buried in the old ruin.  There is a fall from the graveyard.  It is facing the road and it is facing the east.  There were trees growing in it at one time but they are all knocked but one tree.  There is a place in the old ruin where there was a book kept.  It is like a little press in the wall.  It was called the Book of Kilteshill.  It was a great book it was made of parchment.  The old people say it is still in Dublin.  It is a very old graveyard.  There is some idle graveyards in the parish  There were people  bu buried in it
(continues on next page)

4583275/4575824/4606377.title: An Reilig
4583275/4575824/4606377.text:
Níl acht aon roilig sa pharraiste seo .i. Cortún atá cuid de pharraiste Thuma. Tugtar roilig Cortúin ar an roilig sin. Tá sí suidhte in aice an tseipéil atá suidhte ar bóthar atá tuairim is míle soir ón bóthar árd.Cuirtear daoine ins an roilig seo fós. Cuma an litir "l" atá uirthi. Tuairim na bliadhna 1904 ceannuigheadh acra talmhan ó Shéamús Ó Díscín ar seasca punt. Ó chuireadh an talamh sin leis tá an roilig ag dul le fáinne. Tá cúpla thor ag fás thar timcheall na roilige ach níl síad acht an bheag.Tá dhá thuma i gCortún, ceann acu a rinne Major Leonard tuairim is seasca bliadhain ó shoin tar éis báis a athar. Tá doras a dul isteach go dtí an tuaim sin ach chaithfeadh duine an cré do romharadh sul a bhféadfadh sé é a oscailt nó é a feiceál.Cuirtear páistí a bhfágann bás gan baiste i sean lios darbh ainm "Lios a gCrann" atá suidhte ar thalamh Uí Ceannaigh i Síleán. Tuairim is céad bliadhain ó shoin ní raibh aon séipéal i gCortún chor ar bith acht bhí scoil ann agus bhí sé tuairim is leath codh mór is ata an séipéal anois. Fear darbh ainm Padhraic Ó Concubhar a bhi ag múnadh ann. An tam sin theigheadh muinntir na h-aite seo go dtí
(continues on next page)

4583275/4575826/4606379.title: Cartoon Graveyard
4583275/4575826/4606379.text:
There is only one graveyard in the parish of Cortoon that is Cortoon graveyard which is situated near Cortoon church. All the peopleliving in Cortoon parish are buried here. Cortoon parish extends from Killgarrif to Killeen and from Hillswood to Carrea. Cortoongraveyard is composed of about two acres of uneven hilly land which slopes from north to south. There are a good many "thumbs" of bushes growing through out the graveyard and also a few poplar trees on McHugh's side of the graveyard.There is only one tomb in Cortoon graveyard that is where some children of the Lenards are buried. It is like a large stone box about six feet long and two-and- ahalf feet wide. On the top of it there is cut deep into the stone the words "In loving memory of Barbara Lenard beloved child of Luke and Alice Lenard, Queensfort Lodge, Tuam who died on the 15th of June 1901 aged seven years".Young children are usually buried in a lios or fort in Mike McWalter's land in Lisavalley. It is usual for children under seven yearsto be buried there. The place is never called anything but the lios. The graves are made in the middle of the fort itself and some flowers sown over them. This graveyard is well kept. Cortoon graveyard was enlarged about twenty-five years ago.
(continues on next page)

4591091/4589785/4615445.title: A Local Grave
4591091/4589785/4615445.text: A local graveIn a forth in Malachi Mitchells field in Croaghill there is a mound with an old spreading whitethorn growing out of it. It is a local tradition that centurie ago a Danish warrior was buried there and that the whitethorn gew out of his head.

4602674/4594393/4615731.title: Churchyards
4602674/4594393/4615731.text: There are many churchyards in this parish and all are still in use. The ruins of the old Franciscan Abbey are still to be seen in one of them. There are old tombs and monuments inside the ruins and the large one of Lady Matilda Birmingham in amongst them. There are two lovely holywater. Fonts of stone there yet and other beautiful carvings in stone in which the Irish were skilled long ago.The church in the old Dominican Abbey is still in good repair and it belongs to the Protestants now. In the graveyard outside the church there are lovely marble headstones over the graves of gentry named Lobdils. There is a glass coffin enclosed in an iron vault also. About three miles outside the town there is a private graveyard which belongs to a family called Percy who once owned Myode Castle.

4602675/4594486/4616501.title: The Local Graveyards
4602675/4594486/4616501.text:
There are two public grave-yards in my parish, one is situated in the townland of Kiltulla, and the other is situated in the town-land of Killimor. But there are two other private churchyards in the parish also, one of them belongs to the Redemptorist Fathers of the Esker Monastery. The other is situated just beside the Kiltulla church. This is the burial place for all the secular priests of the parish.There are no old ruins in this graveyard, but there are ruins of an old church in the graveyard where the people are buried, and there are also tombs in the public graveyard
(continues on next page)

4602680/4594947/4616507.text:
(continued from previous page)
Dúbhairt an Mistálach leis na feara liomsa do chur isteach agus an corp do thógáil aníos. Rinneadh amlaidh agus badh é seo an t-iasc a bhí níos mó ná an ceann abhí ag na fir bochta.



In the children's graveyard in Kylemore. there is one grave in (Kylemore) it nine feet long where there is a man buried who killed a Giant and the giant he killed is buried on the brink of a nearby lake and on a summer's morning one could see the grave plainly.



Once upon a time there was a priest going on a sick call for nine miles and it was late at night. He asked a man to go with him it was a side-car. they had. On their journey the priest said to the man do you see anything on the side of the road." the man said no well let you come to the other side of me" said the priest.The man did as he was told and they continued their journey. On their return home they stood at a lodge for the night. When the priest went to bed he heard noise in the kitchen it was like the noise of chairs being thrown here and there

4613676/4607536/4616762.title: The Graveyards
4613676/4607536/4616762.text:
I live on the Parish of Clonberne on the borders of the parish of Boyounagh. There are two graveyards in the parish of Boyounagh namely, The Glenamaddy graveyard and the Boyounagh graveyard.The Boyounagh graveyard is north of the village of bashel. It is standing on a high hill and can be seen from the Crossroads of bashel on the Glenamaddy to Dunmore road The Boyounagh graveyard is of a remarkable kind. It is about four feet higher than the surrounding ground. It appears that there were stones and soil brought from other places and scattered around the hill before the boundary wall was made. Long ago when St. Patrick was in Ireland it is said that he came to Boyounagh and established a church on the summit of the hill where the graveyard now stands.After some time
(continues on next page)

4613676/4607551/4616782.title: Graveyards
4613676/4607551/4616782.text:
I live in the Parish of Boyounagh. There are two graveyeards in my Parish namely the Boyounagh Graveyard and the Glenamaddy Graveyard.The Boyounagh graveyard is situated in the townland of Boyounagh. It stands on a high hill and there are a few trees growing on the side of the hill. Long ago when St. Patrick came to Ireland he passed by that hill and he built a small church of timber on top of the hill and that was the first church that was built in the Parish. After a few years this church was condemed and a church of stones was built instead of it in Glenamaddy. About a century ago a few monks came to the Parish and builded a monaster on the ruins of the church. The monastery was made of stones and morther. The blood of animals was
(continues on next page)

4613679/4607858/4623083.text:
There are two grave-yards in this district.One of them is in Glenamaddy and the other is in Boyounagh.There are people buried in each of them.The Glenamaddy grave-yard is faced to the north and the Boyounagh grave-yard is face to the south. There is a ruin of a church in the Glenamaddy grave-yard.The grave-ards a rough with hills and hollows. There are trees and bushes in the Glenamaddy grave-yard.There is a hold in one of
